comments.text:
User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.0; rv:2.0b12pre) Gecko/20110210 Firefox/4.0b12pre
Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.0; rv:2.0b12pre) Gecko/20110210 Firefox/4.0b12pre

Many new malicious sites use obfuscated scripts to redirect, start downloads, modify settings, etc.. I have proposed the need for several new patches.

There should be an option in the "View Page Source" that would attempt to deobfuscate the code, something like JSunpack (http://jsunpack.jeek.org/dec/go), so that users can see the actual intent of the site without hassle.

Also, even though the above would make the code more accessible to the users, there should be browser settings that would limit the access obfuscated code has on the browser, as it is not generally used on harmless sites! Something similar to how you have security setting for JS in Tools -> Options -> Content -> JavaScript (Advanced...)

Reproducible: Always

For what it's worth, there's a JS Deminifier add-on that makes viewing compressed source more pleasant: https://addons.mozilla.org/en-us/firefox/addon/deminifier/

This will only help somewhat with obfuscated code.
